title: Stem attached to fig
vignette: Figs are picked with short stems attached. Does the stem transmit contamination to the fruit?

options.text: Yes, stems count as handles for contamination.
No, they are insignificant once detached from the tree.

title: Leaves around grapes
vignette: Grapes are sold with a few leaves still clinging to the cluster. Are the leaves considered part of the food for contamination?

options.text: They serve as handles so yes.
No, they are mere packaging and ignored.

title: Wilted tops of vegetables
vignette: A bunch of carrots has wilted green tops. Should the tops be removed before considering contamination transfer?

options.text: Remove them; only the root matters now.
Keep them attached—they still transfer contamination.

title: Joining different fruits
vignette: Apples and pears touch inside a basket. Does contamination travel from one to the other via contact?

options.text: Yes, if a handle of one touches the other.
No, they remain separate items.

title: Crushed berries
vignette: Some berries burst during transport leaving juice on the others. Does the juice make the remaining fruit susceptible to contamination?

options.text: Yes, the moisture prepares them for contamination.
No, accidental juice doesn’t count.

title: Removing pits before submersion
vignette: Olives were pitted before being placed in water for purification. Are the pits considered part of the food?

options.text: No, once removed they no longer transmit contamination.
Yes, they are still considered handles.

title: Fruit intended for planting
vignette: Dates selected for sowing fall into contaminated liquid. Do they contract contamination like food?

options.text: No, since they are not meant for eating now.
Yes, any edible item becomes contaminated regardless.

title: Peeling before contact
vignette: A melon will be peeled before eating. If contamination touches the rind now, does the flesh inside become contaminated?

options.text: No, the peel is separate and protects the flesh.
Yes, contact on the peel transfers inside.

title: Broken stalks in bundles
vignette: Wheat stalks tied in bundles have some broken pieces hanging. Do these fragments join the main stalk for contamination?

options.text: Yes, if still attached they transmit contamination.
No, loose fragments are disregarded.

title: Dried husks on nuts
vignette: Almonds with dried outer husks are stored for winter. Is the husk a handle that can transmit contamination?

options.text: Yes, until removed it remains a handle.
No, once dried it is considered separate.

title: Different sizes in one container
vignette: Large and small olives are mixed together. Does contamination to one size affect the other?

options.text: Yes, if they are mixed as one batch.
No, each size is regarded separately.

title: Fruit pressed for juice
vignette: Grapes were pressed and the pomace left in the vat. Does the remaining pulp transmit contamination to new grapes added later?

options.text: Yes, the leftover pulp counts as food residue.
No, once pressed it is no longer significant.

title: Clusters tied together
vignette: Two small clusters are tied to look like one large bundle for sale. Does contamination of one cluster affect the other?

options.text: Yes, tying joins them for contamination purposes.
No, each original cluster remains distinct.

title: Separated grape skins
vignette: After pressing, grape skins are set aside for dye. If contamination touches them, can it spread back to the remaining wine?

options.text: No, once separated they no longer join the wine.
Yes, since they were part of the grapes originally.

title: Fruit sold with protective shells
vignette: Nuts are sold still inside their hard shells. Does contamination on the shell transfer to the nut before cracking?

options.text: No, the shell keeps the nut clean until opened.
Yes, the shell is a handle and conveys contamination.
